inference:
Since $f(x)$ is increasing on $1 \le x \le 3$ and decreasing on $3 \le x \le 6$, $f(x)$ is one-to-one on $1 \le x \le 6$. Therefore, $f(x)$ has an inverse function $f^{-1}(x)$ on $f(1) \le f(x) \le f(6)$. Since the graph of $f(x)$ is symmetric about the line $x = 3$, $f(3)$ is the maximum value of $f(x)$ on $1 \le x \le 6$. Therefore, the maximum value of $f^{-1}(x)$ is $3$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{3}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: We are asked to find the largest value of $x = f^{-1}(y)$, that is the largest value of $x$ for which $f(x)$ exists. Since the point farthest to the right on the graph of $f$ is (6,0), this value is $x = \boxed{6}$. To say it another way, the maximum value of $f^{-1}(x)$ is the largest number in the domain of $f$.
